War in Ukraine: Trump could meet with Putin 'as soon as next week'
subhead: US Special Envoy Steve Witkoff met with the Russian leader on Wednesday to try to convince him to agree to a ceasefire with Ukraine before the August 8 deadline set by the White House. Moscow is considering a concession to delay sanctions on its oil exports.

title: July was Earth's third-warmest on record, EU scientists say
subhead: Despite a somewhat cooler July, the Copernicus Climate Change Service found that the 12-month period between August 2024 and July 2025 was 1.53 degrees above pre-industrial levels, exceeding the threshold set in 2015 to limit human-caused warming to 1.5 degrees.

title: Success of French anti-pesticide petition revives interest in the political tool
subhead: A petition against the 'Duplomb Law' has become the second most signed in French history, and the first of its kind on a parliamentary platform. However, its impact will likely remain symbolic.

title: In rural France, young people keep the local tradition of partying alive
subhead: 'Why Do We Party?' (1/6). In eastern Rignieu-le-Désert, the Amicale Des Jeunes youth association upholds the tradition of local balls, a custom that in some places is now seen as a way of preserving local identity.
byline: By Camille Bordenet (Chazey-sur-Ain (eastern France), special correspondent)

Mojgan Habibi, chef: 'Before, I was afraid of everything. Now, I have found my freedom'
subhead: 'Refuge Recipes' (4/6). Iranian native Mojgan Habibi is the breakfast chef at Hôtel du Couvent in Nice. Khoresht mast, a dish reserved for special occasions and made with yogurt, spices, honey and meat, brings back memories of her happy youth in Isfahan before her marriage, when she was free to create and sing.

title: Agnès Varda's Parisian wanderings at the Musée Carnavalet
subhead: An original exhibition focuses on the artist's relationship with Paris, highlighting her photographic work and her atelier in the 14th arrondissement.

title: Eighty years after Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombings, the fight for survivors' memories to live on
subhead: In Japan, the two cities have long promoted peace and nuclear disarmament, led by survivors of the 1945 nuclear bombings. As their voices fade, both cities are striving to carry their message forward.
byline: By Philippe Mesmer (Hiroshima and Nagasaki, special correspondent)
